linkTarget.anchoringText: Conventional PDC cutters drill formations by a shearing process, whereas CDEs drill formations by combining shearing and plowing rock-destruction mechanisms. The cutters' unique conical geometry, combined with an ultrathick polycrystalline diamond layer (Fig. 1), provide superior impact strength and wear resistance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The CDE's conical geometry and ultrathick PCD layer provide multiple advantages over conventional PDC cutting elements.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The CDE's conical geometry and ultrathick PCD layer provide multiple advantages over conventional PDC cutting elements.

linkTarget.anchoringText: These conical elements are strategically placed across the bit face, resulting in a step change in drilling performance. These elements are placed from gauge to bit center (Fig. 2) using a finite-element analysis (FEA) -based modeling system. The new design strengthens the overall cutting structure compared with conventional fixed-cutter PDC bits.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: (a) A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups or (b) be fully equipped with CDEs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups or (b) be fully equipped with CDEs.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups

linkTarget.anchoringText: To ensure CDE robustness, significant research and development were invested to refine the design and manufacturing processes to optimize the element's material properties. Although the CDEs are made of polycrystalline diamond, similar to conventional PDC cutters, they are manufactured using proprietary equipment to achieve the necessary pressures, resulting in their significant impact strength and wear resistance. Compared with a conventional PDC cutter, a CDE is approximately twice as thick at the conical tip (Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Ultrathick CDE diamond table provides superior impact strength and wear resistance compared with PDC cutters.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ultrathick CDE diamond table provides superior impact strength and wear resistance compared with PDC cutters.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To quantitatively measure the CDE's impact strength compared with a conventional PDC cutter, a series of laboratory tests were conducted using a singlecutter device. Both elements were dropped onto a hardened steel block with an impact force of 18,000 lbf (80,000 N). The experiment simulated transitional drilling by a PDC bit exiting soft shale and then encountering hard limestone at a 60 ft/hr ROP. The conventional PDC cutter suffered catastrophic failure on first impact, which completely destroyed the cutter's sharp edge (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: (a) The PDC cutter failed on the first impact; however, (b) the CDE survived 100 impacts without damage.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) The PDC cutter failed on the first impact; however, (b) the CDE survived 100 impacts without damage.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The PDC cutter failed on the first impact
the CDE survived 100 impacts without damage.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using data from both tests, hard-material scientists determined the CDE's thick diamond table essentially doubles its impact strength and improves the wear resistance by approximately 25 to 30% compared with a conventional premium PDC cutters (Fig. 5). These properties suggest CDE bits have great potential for improving run lengths and penetration rates in impact-prone applications, including hard interbedded formations and conglomerates, in transitional drilling, and in formations containing pyrite and chert.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: The CDE's thick diamond table produces greater wear resistance and impact strength compared with a PDC bit.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The CDE's thick diamond table produces greater wear resistance and impact strength compared with a PDC bit.

linkTarget.anchoringText: After laboratory testing, engineers wanted to determine how the CDE would fail in difficult rock formations. An FEA-based modeling system was used to avoid costly and time-consuming field trials. The laboratory testing determined the CDE would produce concentrated point loading capable of failing in high-compressive strength formations more effectively than conventional PDC cutters (Fig. 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: FEA modeling shows the CDE (b) bits produce higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter (a).

formatted-caption.caption-text: FEA modeling shows the CDE (b) bits produce higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter (a).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: bits produce higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter

linkTarget.anchoringText: When developing the new CDE bits, designers surmised that the plowing action created by the CDE would produce less torque than a conventional PDC cutter that aggressively shears the formation. To test the hypothesis, extensive laboratory testing was performed, which confirmed that conical elements drill with an average of 26% less torque than conventional PDC cutters (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: As ROP increases, a CDE (green) drills with 26% less torque compared with conventional PDC cutters (gray), providing better directional response and smoother tool face control.

formatted-caption.caption-text: As ROP increases, a CDE (green) drills with 26% less torque compared with conventional PDC cutters (gray), providing better directional response and smoother tool face control.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Unwanted lateral and axial vibration that occurs during the wellbore construction process reduces drilling efficiency. The undesirable drillstring harmonics require additional mechanical specific energy input to the system, which can lower ROP and reduce run lengths. Engineers used FEA modeling to compare a standard PDC cutter with the CDE. The results showed that the CDE has a more balanced force profile when the CDE and PDC cutter are placed across the bit face (Fig. 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: FEA modeling shows the resultant lateral force of the CDE is much lower than a PDC cutter when the CDE and PDC cutter are placed across a cutting structure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: FEA modeling shows the resultant lateral force of the CDE is much lower than a PDC cutter when the CDE and PDC cutter are placed across a cutting structure.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a bit design comparison, modeling confirmed the balanced profile equates to less lateral force per cutting element on CDE bits compared with conventional PDCs mitigating shock and vibration (Fig. 9). The increased bit and BHA stability translates into higher ROP and footage totals while prolonging the operating life of costly downhole measurement and steering tools. The reduction in vibration using CDE bits was then confirmed in a south Texas field test (Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: In a simulated drilling operatlonthrough a30,000-psl Ilmestoneatl8,000-lbf weight- on-bit, the CDE bit (b) had 86% less lateral vibration than a conventional PDC bit (a).

formatted-caption.caption-text: In a simulated drilling operatlonthrough a30,000-psl Ilmestoneatl8,000-lbf weight- on-bit, the CDE bit (b) had 86% less lateral vibration than a conventional PDC bit (a).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a bit design comparison, modeling confirmed the balanced profile equates to less lateral force per cutting element on CDE bits compared with conventional PDCs mitigating shock and vibration (Fig. 9). The increased bit and BHA stability translates into higher ROP and footage totals while prolonging the operating life of costly downhole measurement and steering tools. The reduction in vibration using CDE bits was then confirmed in a south Texas field test (Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: In field tests, the CDE bit produced 53% and 37% less (a) lateral and (b) axial vibrations, respectively.

formatted-caption.caption-text: In field tests, the CDE bit produced 53% and 37% less (a) lateral and (b) axial vibrations, respectively.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Laboratory testing revealed the concentrated point loading created by the CDE's unique conical geometry generates large drill cuttings at the rigsite. In field tests, CDE bits produced a significant amount of 2-mm cuttings by volume when compared with cuttings produced by conventional PDC bits in similar formations (Fig. 11). The large gravel-size chips enabled wellsite geologists to more accurately measure the formation's mineralogy, porosity, permeability, and hydrocarbon content.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: (a) The standard PDC bit produced small cuttings when drilling limestone with high chert content, while (b) the CDE bit generated larger cuttings in the same formation, which greatly enhanced formation evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) The standard PDC bit produced small cuttings when drilling limestone with high chert content, while (b) the CDE bit generated larger cuttings in the same formation, which greatly enhanced formation evaluation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stretching across the Gulf of Thailand for a distance of 500 km is the Pattani basin, one of the richest sources of hydrocarbons in Thailand. Block G10/48 in the southern Pattani basin (Fig. 12), covering 4700 sq. km, has been intermittently explored since 1975. In 2009, three important discoveries were made of which the Wassana is the largest oil discovery with 13 million barrels of recoverable oil. The 1500 m of rock above the reservoir is not complex to drill but the oil is strapped in multiple locations within the thin layers of fluvial sandstone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Offshore block G10/48 in the Wassana field, southern Gulf of Thailand some 130 km northeast of Songkhla.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Offshore block G10/48 in the Wassana field, southern Gulf of Thailand some 130 km northeast of Songkhla.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Directional. Build and hold a long tangent section, which turns or drops towards the end. The drop or turn near the end was challenging because the bit cutting structure invariably becomes damaged (see Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Planned directional profile with build, hold tangent, and deep turn towards the end.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Planned directional profile with build, hold tangent, and deep turn towards the end.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Formation. Formations below 5,000 TVD are hard, abrasive, and highly interbedded, in addition to containing of traces of pyrites as shown in Fig. 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Rock strength analysis and lithological description using a mud log.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rock strength analysis and lithological description using a mud log.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The conventional PDC bits stop drilling due to cutting structure damage; hence, the ability to drill beyond 5,500-ft TVD was a major challenge because most of the bits had to be tripped after 5,000 ft TVD (Fig. 15)

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Dull condition of conventional PDC cutting structures.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dull condition of conventional PDC cutting structures.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The CDE bit runs were more stable with less vibration than conventional PDC bits (Fig. 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Vibration signatures of conventional PDC bits vs. CDE bits.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Vibration signatures of conventional PDC bits vs. CDE bits.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Formation. The CDE bits allowed for drilling deeper to TVD without the need to trip out for bit change, all of which resulted in planning to explore deeper formations (Fig. 17).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Performance comparison of conventional PDC bits and CDE bits.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Performance comparison of conventional PDC bits and CDE bits.
